text: Rheumatoid arthritis ( RA ) is characterized by infiltrations of macrophages and T cells into the joint , and synovial hyperplasia .
Proinflammatory cytokines released from these cells are known to be important in the destruction of joints in RA [ 1 ] .

The favorable clinical benefits obtained with inhibitors of <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and <extra_id_0> interleukin (IL)-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> suggest that the blockade of key inflammatory cytokines has been the important issue in the development of new therapeutic applications [ 2 ] .
A little over a decade ago , the primacy of T cells in the pathogenesis of autoimmune disease such as RA was undisputed because they are the largest cell population infiltrating the synovium .

However , a series of studies demonstrated paucity of T cell-derived cytokines such as <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> interferon-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the joints of RA , whereas macrophage and fibroblast cytokines including <extra_id_0> IL-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-15 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-18 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> were abundant in rheumatoid synovium .
This paradox has questioned the role of T cells in the pathogenesis of RA [ 3 ] .

Because we have already demonstrated the enhanced proliferation of antigen specific T cells , especially to type II collagen , and the skewing of T helper type 1 ( Th1 ) cytokines in RA [ 4 ] , the role of T cells needs to be elucidated in different aspects .

<extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is one of the inflammatory cytokines secreted mainly by activated T cells , which can induce <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> by fibroblasts [ 5 ] .

This cytokine is of interest for two major reasons : first , similarly to <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has proinflammatory properties ; second , it is produced by T cells [ 6 ] .

Recent observations demonstrated that <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can also activate osteoclastic bone resorption by the induction of <extra_id_0> RANKL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> receptor activator of nuclear factor kappaB [NF-kappaB] ligand <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , which is involved in bony erosion in RA [ 7 ] .

It also stimulates the production of <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> leukemia inhibitory factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> by synoviocytes , and of prostaglandin E2 and nitric oxide by chondrocytes , and has the ability to differentiate and activate the dendritic cells [ 8-10 ] .

Levels of <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in synovial fluids were significantly higher in patients with RA than in patients with osteoarthritis ( OA ) , and it was produced by <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells in the synovium [ 11 , 12 ] .

<extra_id_0> IL-15 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , secreted from activated macrophages , has been reported to be an important trigger of <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production in RA peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) by cyclosporine and steroid sensitive pathways [ 13 ] .

Recently , Happel and colleagues also showed that <extra_id_0> IL-23 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> could be an efficient trigger of <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production from both <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + and <extra_id_0> CD8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells [ 14 ] .

Although the contribution of <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in joint inflammation in RA has been documented in earlier studies [ 12 , 15 , 16 ] , the intracellular signal transduction pathway for <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production remains uncertain .
In the present study we used various stimuli to investigate <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production in PBMC of patients with RA and its signaling transduction pathway .

We found that the intracellular signaling pathway involving phosphoinositide 3-kinase ( PI3K ) / <extra_id_0> Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and NF-kappaB might be involved in the overproduction of the key inflammatory cytokine <extra_id_0> IL-17 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in RA .
These results might provide new insights into the pathogenesis of RA and future directions for new therapeutic strategies in RA .
